title: Tuesday, 22nd November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hi there

PM11:02am

Bull market is back on

PM11:02am

You almost got a picture of Farage as the pic for today

11:02 am
PM11:02am

But I managed to avoid it

PM11:03am

Political newsflow continues to be nuts

PM11:03am

Really does

But it's actually moved beyond parody. So we just have to try and ignore it all, I guess

But I will ask them to fix this issue when they can

I guess so. For old-times' sake.

undefined
BE11:09am

So everything with results is down and everything without results is up.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

That's what we're doing today.

BE11:10am

We're selling everyone who's actually conceded within the last couple of hours that trading's a bit rubbish, or that costs are up, or that FX doesn't always move advantageously for them.

BE11:10am

Everyone else is surely fine though? Buy them.

11:10 am

hehehe

PM11:11am

BE11:11am

Babcock requested on the right, which is as good a place to start as any.

11:11 am
Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 941.00, down 50 (-5.05%), High: 1,006, Low: 933.50, Volume: 1.25m
PM11:11am

Ouch

PM11:12am

Interims here: http://www.investe...1611220700097634P/

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Ultra-defensive nailed on government defence contractor, can write its figures five years in advance within 5% of the actuality .....

BE11:12am

..... Except not, it turns out. Organic growth weaker than expected.

BE11:13am

Goldman incoming with the summary.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Babcock reported slightly weaker-than-expected 1H16 results this morning, with organic growth of 4% vs. our expectations of 5%. Total revenues and EBITA including JVs was broadly in line (1% ahead) with our estimates as the company benefited from FX and delivered stable profitability. The bid pipeline was replenished successfully and is up to £10.8bn (from £10.5bn at end FY16), reflecting a £3bn intake during the period. Revenue visibility is strong, with 93%/63% of FY17/FY18 revenue already under contract. The group pension deficit went up by £60mn y-o-y, reflecting the change in interest rates (up to £261mn). Cash conversion post capex was 79%, up from 73% in 1H16. The outlook for FY17 was, as usual, qualitative, with Babcock expecting continued good progress for both this year and beyond. Despite the slightly slower organic growth in 1H17, the board expects the full-year results to be in line with its expectations.

BE11:13am

Overall, 1H17 was slightly weaker-than-expected owing to more
pronounced phasing of revenues towards 2H. The organic growth
slowdown in 1H17 was largely driven by support services on a slowdown in decommissioning JVs. We believe the company is well on track to deliver 6.8% yoy organic growth rate for the full year supported by improving bid pipeline and stable win rates. While slower 1H growth rates might create some concerns over the outlook, in our view the market expectations were already for organic growth to be weighted more to 2H.

PM11:13am

In line, and yet down 5%

11:13 am
BE11:14am

Second-half phasing's going to be phrase of the day, I suspect.

BE11:14am

There's a lot of it around. "We'll make numbers when things improve".

BE11:14am

Which investors tend to hear as "We'll make numbers if things improve".

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Hmm

BE11:16am

Jefferies as well.

BE11:16am

Kean Marden, rather than Sandy. They class it as support services rather than defence I guess.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

On track to meet consensus FY17E expectations. Outlook comments stress that “despite slightly slower organic revenue growth, the Board expects the full-year results to be in line with its expectations. We therefore remain confident of making good progress both this year and beyond”. In our view, FY17E consensus organic revenue growth estimates may drift to c.4% given the H1 trajectory but higher margins offset, and EPS estimates are likely to remain unchanged.

Reiterate Buy rating. Our unchanged 1330p price target applies a 17x CY16E PE multiple, which should be attainable given a 9-19x through-the-cycle historical range. At the current share price, the FY17E FCF yield is 5.3% and 6.1% before the additional cash pension payment. Risks include mobilising increasingly large contracts and managing international expansion.

undefined
PM11:17am

So same forces at place with Compass?

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Got it in one.

PM11:17am

We'll make the numbers when things improve...

PM11:17am

When not if

11:17 am
PM11:17am

http://www.investe...1611220700107660P/

BE11:18am

FY is okay, but it's an FX bump ..........

BE11:18am

Underlying, pretty ordinary.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Our expectations for 2017 are positive, with growth weighted to the second half of the year.

PM11:19am

So the market says...

Compass Group PLC (CPG:LSE): Last: 1,317, down 74 (-5.32%), High: 1,386, Low: 1,306, Volume: 3.62m
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Underpinning this seems to be the idea that UK business will come back, post the obvious.

BE11:19am

Quick line from Cazenove ......

BE11:19am

Europe should decelerate “a fraction” in 2017, which is the clearest risk to our forecasts (JPMe stable trends at 2.8% in FY17e after 2.8% in FY16e). Q1 growth could be similar or a fraction worse to the flat Q4 exit rate. But after “maybe a little bit of a slowdown in decision-making” in the UK immediately after the EU referendum vote, the UK pipeline and signed contracts are now supportive of a “sharp acceleration” into H217 (the UK represents 10% of group revenue or 36% of Europe). Retention rates in the wider region “continue to inch up”. It is too early to factor in margin benefits from the replication of the FoodBuy model, with total FoodBuy Europe purchasing being close to £200m, compared to $20bn in the US. We estimate that -1.5pt lower organic growth in the region has a -0.4% EPS impact for the group.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

And for the broader view, have Canaccord.

BE11:21am

Compass's prelims are in line with expectations, with North America again acting as the powerhouse division. The company is positive for FY17 but warns that growth will be H2 weighted. With political and economic uncertainty gripping the FTSE250, we think Compass represents a safe-haven and that seems unlikely to change in the immediate future. Although there is a very good correlation between sterling weakness and its share price strength this year, our BUY recommendation is also rooted on our positive view of the underlying outlook for Compass.

BE11:21am

Detail
Underlying operating profit rose by 5.6% to £1,445m with EPS rising by 7.8% to 61.1p.
Compass delivered excellent Group organic growth of +5.0% with North America recording +8.1%, Europe +2.8% and RoW +3.6% (excluding Offshore & Remote). Group margin was flat at 7.1% as the company made margin investment in Europe to create nine sub-regional business units.
Compass generates only c10-12% of EBIT in the UK and a 1% change in a basket of all its currencies has a £12m impact on EBIT. The major currency is the US$ and a five US cents move has a c£20m impact on full year EBIT; a five Euro cents move in the €:£ is worth c£7.5m. Although Compass operates in c.50 countries, eight account for c83% of revenue in aggregate: USA, UK, Canada, France, Australia, Brazil, Germany and Japan. For the cable we assume US$1.43 for FY16 and £1.30 thereafter; for the Euro we assume €1.30 for FY16 and €1.20 thereafter.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Post Brexit, the share price rose by 18% to its early October high-point. Since then it has fallen by 10% but is still up by 32% over the last 12 months. At Friday's close, Compass was valued on a PE of 23.1x for FY16E falling to 19.5x for FY17E and EV/EBITDA of 14.0x, falling to 12.2x the following year. Despite the recent profit taking, it remains expensive versus a five-year average of 17.1x and ten-year average of 16.2x.

BE11:22am

Compass still runs Rhodes 24, doesn't it?

BE11:23am

That place up the Natwest Tower. Well, in the middle of the Natwest Tower. It's ............... catering, undoubtedly.

11:22 am

11:26 am

BE11:27am

BE11:27am

Have a summary from Investec.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

1H shows strong sales, with Film recovering and heavy release costs in the period; we see this as positive with 2H prospects good. TV and Family are still strong. We remain Buyers for content value upside. Valuation attractive vs content peers: CY17E adj. EV/EBITDA c.8x and P/E 11.6x. Forecasts unchanged; ETO suggests FY on track with a strong 2H expected and good visibility. FY ETO guidance of 1.1-1.2x core net debt/EBITDA (ex production finance) vs forecast (1.0x), mostly offset by lower production finance.

1H sales £401m (+19%) vs f/c £392m, with LFL +3%, FX +10% and M&A +6%. Adj. EBITD £38m (£52m), vs f/c £40m, given big Film release costs and MGC royalty accrual wash out (£4.5m). Adj PTP £21m (£58m) vs f/c £23m post SBP (£2.8m), and adj EPS 2.3p (8p) vs f/c 2.9p. 1H debt seasonally higher as usual at £263m (£250m 1H15) plus production finance at £139m (£79m) given content cost phasing, vs FY17E £359m (incl production finance £190m).
Film prospects better: sales £242m (+9%) as f/c, with theatrical +87% on strong box office post Amblin (e.g. BFG). Home Ent (-26%) and Broadcast and Digital (-6%) hit by poor prior year films. Loss of £2m, vs f/c breakeven, due to big film launch P&A (marketing)/amortisation, but implies better 2H high margin ancillary revenues. Outlook suggests good visibility/strong pipeline.
TV momentum: sales £144m (+34%) vs f/c £139m, with core production +20%, slightly below f/c (timing), and MGC above at +268% (new commission flow through). TV profit is £18.5m (-8%), as f/c, with core flat (timing) and MGC down (but up ex the 1H15 £4.5m accrual write-back). Core TV FY target remains 1100 half hours (+10%) with good drama re-commissions and delivery 2H skewed. International distribution is strong. MGC comment is positive with Designated Survivor outperforming, but Conviction underperforming.
Family: 1H sales £38m (+16%) with EBITD £25m (+13%), as f/c. Peppa momentum internationally, with US strong; sales +275% with merchandise demand above expectations, plans for increased SKU count and the new 52 episode series delivered this year. China comment suggests good initial momentum. PJ Masks growth is strong, with US merchandise launching well.
Board: Giles Willits, CFO steps down after 10 yrs; a surprise, but Interim CFO is Joe Sparacio, ex CFO of IMAX (9 yrs), iN DEMAND and Loews Cineplex Ent.

https://www.ft.com...-a37c-f4a01f1b0fa1

BE11:44am

The Treasury will announce more than £400m to expand Britain’s “full-fibre” broadband network as part of the Autumn Statement on Wednesday.

The new money will be matched by private finance and is designed to spur more than £1bn of investment into building fibre-optic cables that reach from internet service providers all the way into homes and businesses.

The money will also be spent on rolling out broadband in the countryside and the funding of 5G trials.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Which brings us back to Sky.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 760.95, up 10.45 (+1.39%), High: 769.50, Low: 755.00, Volume: 2.23m
BE11:47am

Credit Suisse doing the knife catching there.

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Brave of them

BE11:47am

We initiate with an Outperform rating and 980p TP: Investor sentiment on Sky is extremely negative due to structural concerns about Over-The-Top (OTT) TV and sports inflation. It has underperformed the FTSE100 by 38% and a weak Stoxx 600 Media by 12% YTD. We acknowledge that there are legitimate concerns about competition, the economy and sports inflation, but believe that these are overdone at current levels. Our view is supported by our proprietary UK consumer survey, which shows the complementarity of OTT and Sky’s pay TV business. In addition, we believe the stock is not discounting the possibility of a bid from 21st Century Fox.

PM11:48am

Any mention of piracy in there?

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Not much.

BE11:48am

On that last point though ... And, as we noted in the paper overnight, Sky's now 16% cheaper (in dollar terms) than the rejected 2010 bid from News Corp (as was)

BE11:49am

Though anyone wanting to read Murdoch's mind is more than welcome to try .......

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Sky is still a strong business at an attractive valuation: We estimate a Free Cash Flow CAGR of more than 8% over this rights cycle (including Premier League and Bundesliga step-ups and box costs moving into capex and excluding one-offs from property and integration). It was resilient in the 2009 economic crisis with greater than 7% revenue growth, 5% customer growth and flat churn. We think it has opportunities in UK mobile and in Europe, for which
consensus expectations are low.

BE11:50am

Catalysts and Risks: Catalysts include Q2 results, mobile launch data and potential 21st Century Fox bid. Risks include: lower net adds, additional costs for mobile, UK economic pressure, next Premier League and Champions League auctions and a potential further de-rating.

BE11:50am

Valuation: Our TP of 980p is based on a Discounted Cash Flow
methodology. Our forecast calendarised FCF yield is 6.3% in 2017E rising to 8.1% in 2018E. Our 2018E EPS is c.3.5% below IBES consensus as we have factored in UK advertising declines in both fiscal 2017 and 2018. Dividend yield is 4.4% vs the media sector (ex-internet) on 4.0%. Our valuation is supported by the warranted price of 1011p in HOLT, based on our estimates.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

BE11:51am

Guess how many mentions of "piracy"?

PM11:51am

BE11:51am

BE11:51am

BE11:52am

Vodafone Group PLC (VOD:LSE): Last: 202.15, no change, High: 202.75, Low: 199.65, Volume: 29.47m
BE11:53am

Exane, with a cracking front page.

BE11:56am

11:56 am
PM11:56am

BE11:56am

BE11:57am

11:57 am
BE11:57am

The launch of Reliance Jio, a new pan-Indian mobile

operator, is set to take competition to unparalleled highs,

and prices to unmatched lows. Our granular review of

regional subscriber and spectrum share shows the ‘least

bad option’ for Vodafone is to merge with Idea Cellular,

as a first step to a full scale exit. We hope such a move

might lead to a wider debate about Vodafone’s future in

Emerging Markets.

Our downgrades to AMAP estimates, India in particular,

lead to our price target being cut to 230p/share, implying

limited upside. Crucially, our European valuation of 7.0x

EBITDA is a premium to peers. As such we downgrade

to Neutral.

BE11:57am

Getting past the cover, it's a serious bit of work.

BE11:58am

“What is Sankara?” “Fortune and glory kid. Fortune and glory”

Offering an opportunity to tap into a potential greater than 1.3bn sim-card market, telecom operators from around the world have flocked to India in search of fortune and glory. Unfortunately, high competition and regulation have meant that none have prospered. And with the entry of Reliance Jio, the likelihood of returning a cost of capital appears doubtful. Faced with this bleak outlook, we believe Vodafone must ‘deal’ to avoid further value destruction.

Vodafone India – a Jio-normous problem

The entry of Reliance Jio has been met with a huge fanfare – it has generated 16m subs one month post launch. The Big 3 operators, Bharti, Vodafone and Idea Cellular, will hope that Jio’s momentum slows as it begins to charge for services. However, Jio’s unlimited voice/data heavy tariff structure should significantly limit market growth. In response, we reduce our Vodafone India EBITDA estimates by EUR500m in the near term, and close to greater than EUR800m in the longer term.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

An Idea for India – 50:50 merger a solution

We have painstakingly undertaken a ‘circle-by-circle’ review of subscriber and spectrum market share. In so doing, we show that a merger with Idea Cellular is feasible, would only require modest spectrum sales, and allow Vodafone to push EUR6bn of HoldCo debt to OpCo.

Moreover, a deal would provide Vodafone a liquid Indian currency to further de-equitise, and generate synergies with an NPV of EUR5bn-7bn, worth ~6p/share after tax.

BE11:59am

Ages since I've looked at India mobile. Good to see it's no more sane than it ever was.

11:32 am
PM11:32am

ETO reported interims showing a 19% growth in revenues, and adjusted EBITDA of £37.7m marking a 28% decline YoY. Management is guiding to a strong second half performance, citing the timing of investment in its strong first-half film slate for the lower profit out-turn and says it is on track to deliver full-year numbers in line with its expectations.
Film reported a 9% increase in revenues, marking a sharp improvement from the run-rate in FY16, with theatrical revenues up 87% YoY. There were 88 theatrical releases generating box office takings up 55% to US$152m, driven by some notable titles including The BFG, which grossed over £30m in the UK. Since the end of the period, The Girl on The Train has delivered over £23m at the UK box office. Profits should start to flow through more positively as content moves into ancillary windows.
Television reported revenues up 34% YoY, and LfL EBITDA up 18% to £18.5m. 360 out of a total expected 1,100 half hours of acquired/produced content were delivered in the period, and management claims 86% of its full-year revenues in this division are already delivered, contracted or commissioned, lending greater support to expectations for the second half. Mark Gordon also reported a positive result, with underlying EBITDA up 15% LfL, and the first deliveries of Designated Survivor a key highlight of the period. Family performed well, with revenues and profits 16% and 13% ahead respectively. Peppa Pig has seen strong merchandise demand in the US market, and was the best-selling pre-school girls' toy licensed property in the US during September.
Operationally the first half has seen encouraging progress, with most TV content being delivered in H2 and the recovery in the Film division taking time to flow through to the bottom line. However, in our view management will now need to deliver a strong profit performance in order to meet full-year consensus estimates, with little room for error, which raises the risk profile of the investment. We remain cautious.
Lastly, CFO Giles Willitts is stepping down after nearly ten years with the group. He is being replaced on an interim basis by Joe Sparacio, previously CFO of IMAX.
